chapter.title: Creating a CDI Web Project
chapter.para: From the workbench go to FileNewOther.

figure.title: Selecting the CDI Web Project wizard

textobject.phrase: Wizard selection screen with the CDI Web Project wizard selected.

chapter.para: The first screen of the wizard will ask you to define the attributes according to the options outlined in . Click the Next button after defining the attributes in order to continue customizing your project or click the Finish button to accept all other defaults and create your application.

textobject.phrase: The main options to define and select for your project.

row.entry: The project name can be any name you define.

The Use default location checkbox will be selected automatically to define the project location as the Eclipse workspace. However you can define a custom path in the Location field be deselecting the Use default location checkbox.
The default location corresponds to the Eclipse workspace.
Select a pre-configured runtime from the available options or configure a new runtime environment.

entry.para: The target runtime defines the server to which the application will be deployed.

row.entry: Select the required web module version.

entry.para: This option adds support for the Java Servlet API with module versions corresponding to JEE or J2EE levels as listed in .

row.entry: Select the project configuration from the available options.

entry.para: The project can be based on either a custom or a set of pre-defined configurations as described in .

row.entry: Add the project to an existing EAR project.

entry.para: The project can be added to an existing EAR project by selecting the checkbox. Once checked, a new EAR project can be defined by clicking the New Project button.

row.entry: Add the project to an existing working set.

entry.para: A working set provides the ability to group projects or project attributes in a customized way to improve access. A new working set can be defined once the Select button has been clicked.

Depending on the runtime configuration, you may have to manually add CDI facet support through the Modify button.

Total manual configuration is required through the Modify button. Ensure you enable the CDI facet for CDI Web Project creation to succeed.

chapter.para: The Java configuration screen allows you to define Source folders on the build path and the Default output folder. The defaults for each are recommended, however you have the option to change them as you see fit.

textobject.phrase: Java configuration screen for your project.

chapter.para: The Web Module configuration screen allows you to define the Context root and the Content directory to be created, the option to Generate web.xml deployment descriptor is selected by default. The defaults for each are recommended, however you have the option to change them as you see fit.

textobject.phrase: Web Module configuration screen for your project.

chapter.para: The Context and Dependency Injection (CDI) Facet settings configuration screen allows you to Generate beans.xml file, selected by default. The beans.xml file is a bean archive descriptor that allows you to enable CDI services for a bean archive. It is recommended that you leave the option selected.

textobject.phrase: Web Module configuration screen for your project.

chapter.para: The final wizard screen pertains to JSF Capabilities configuration.

textobject.phrase: JSF Capabilities configuration screen for your project.
